ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the history of music, from troubadours in France to Italian madrigals to German Lied to modern love songs (ex. Regina Spektor, Beyonc). We learned various musical terms that were relevant to the genres we were discussing.
looking at music more deeply and better analyzing symbolism within the construction of music itself as well as the historical significance of songs
I learned a lot about the history of western, specifically European, music and how it changed over the years.

This class teaches you how to identify the interactions between song lyrics, song notes, and song accompaniment. More importantly, you learn the history behind today's modern day love songs--the good and the bad. That being said, the history is very euro-centric.

This course has allowed me to become a better listener. I can identify musical techniques and determine cultural influences when listening to music. The journey of 1000 years has been eye opening and I feel like I can listen to music with a deeper perspective
Knowledge of the history of songs about love and sex. Analytical skills (writing and discussion based).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very freeform/chill, which is mostly a strength but can occasionally be a weakness when the readings aren't posted until a night before they're due or the final isn't posted and it's almost reading period. In general, though, this course is really fun and provides an interesting look at the history of music. The readings are usually interesting and the songs are too. Prof Z definitely wants people to succeed in the course and is supportive. The midterm is the only test (which is great -- most of the grade is from other stuff) and it required a lot of memorization of terms, but ultimately wasn't too bad. The course also doesn't assume any prereqs/music theory knowledge.
The class was really interesting. I think the music was really fun and the lecture format was really nice.

Strengths: thoughtfully planned lectures, engaging professor, light workload, quick-ish feedback on short responses, reasonable tests
Weaknesses: some awkward silent pauses (during zoom), sometimes somewhat surface level discussions, readings could be kinda dense/boring at times

Strengths; nice sense of community, good feedback, interesting and extensive syllabus. Engaging professor and TF. 
Weakness: Some weeks had too many readings, made it hard to retain so much info. Professor seemed to be a bit distant/uninterested in students at times, also seemed to shame/punish students who used their previous music and music theory knowledge in the class discussions or assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a seminar so it was built around discussion. I thought choosing three people to give their thoughts on the homework worked well (at least better than just having people volunteer, since I think people are less likely to just speak out on a Zoom call than in an in-person scenario).
covid makes it hard, this class made it easy to learn but hard to engage with classmates and learn more about the people
The collaborative listening guide was an interesting way to learn about what my other classmates had to say about the music we were listening to.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course if you're open to learning about/listening to/discussing new musical genres. This course really gives you a broad and interesting overview of music from the 12th century to today. The course is not too much work and usually the homework is to listen to a few songs/pieces and read one or two readings, and then in class you discuss the homework and sometimes watch presentations on related content.

Maybe. I would have to clearly explain what the course is about. When I signed up for the class, I thought there would be less focus on non-english music made before the 1600s. However, I did enjoy some of the things that I learned about.

Yes absolutely!! The course has a very manageable course load, along with a FANTASTIC professor (and TA). The course was very accessible, even for someone with little music experience like me. I imagine that this FYS would be even better in person, so take this course if you get the chance!

This course is very interesting. From its eye catching title to its broad musical appeal, it is a stimulating course for music lovers. This class also takes into account the greater social context of songs allowing us to get a more holistic view of issues they may bring up.
Yes, absolutely. Very cool and fascinating. Good energy to the course. Great professor and TF.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
